Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Does genetic similarity of trees explain beta diversity of soil microbes and the strength of negative plant-soil feedbacks in a tropical tree population?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Adult trees in tropical forests prevent their offspring from sprouting nearby. This parent-offspring interaction can explain high species diversity in tropical forests. The genetic foundation for this negative interaction will be investigated. The genetic diversity of mature trees, seedlings, and bacteria and fungi in the soil will be assessed. The mechanisms by which pathogen-resistant genes influence reproduction and maintain diversity will be examined. Efforts in conservation and in tropical reforestation will be aided by this information. The project will strengthen the scientific workforce by training a graduate student in genetic techniques.

This study will be among the first to incorporate a genetic mechanism into the classical Janzen-Connell hypothesis of seedling survival and diversity maintenance in tropical forests. New evidence has shown that negative plant-soil feedbacks between tropical trees and their pathogens are genotype-specific (i.e., trees within a population respond differently to the same soil microbiome). Whether plant-soil feedbacks in tropical tree communities are genetically controlled will be determined for tree-seedling genetic similarity, for tree-tree genetic similarity, and for microbial community - tree community genetic similarity. Analyses of the genetics will complement experiments on the conditions in which pathogen-resistant genes affect population dynamics. The degree of similarities will elucidate the biological and spatial scales at which the interactions are effective. Training in genetic and metagenomics techniques and bioinformatics will provide research experience for the student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the role of microbes in diverse natural ecosystems, such as tropical forests, is a central goal in the field of ecology and is crucial to the conservation and management of these systems. The goal of this project was to address a novel hypothesis about how microbes in the soil affect the fate of seedlings in tropical tree populations. From our previous studies, we knew that soil microbes can cause tropical tree seedlings to grow less near a close relative (such as their parent) than near other adults of their species, which could play an important role in promoting diversity in tree communities. To build on this finding, we proposed that the genes that determine susceptibility or resistance to pathogens vary among trees in the same population. Shared susceptibility to pathogens between parent and offspring could produce the pattern we observed previously: seedlings might grow less near their parents because they share resistance genes and are susceptible to the pathogens that proliferate near their parent. The combination of resistance genes and soil environments (i.e., parent vs. non-parent) could also shape seedling root microbiomes. To address these hypotheses, we used next-generation genetic sequencing techniques to examine resistance genes and root fungal communities in a tropical tree population in a diverse forest in Panama.

Intellectual merit: We obtained resistance gene and/or root fungal community data from 15 adults and >150 seedlings of a tropical tree species. Preliminary analyses combining these new molecular data with prior experimental data on these same individuals yielded several novel results in support of our hypotheses. Overall, we found large variation in resistance genotypes and root fungal communities among the adults and seedlings in our study population. Seedling genotypes varied in their overall fungal diversity, and we found several examples of genotype-specific associations between root fungal species and resistance genotypes, suggesting that tropical soil microbes are genotype-specific. In addition, whether a seedling was grown in the soil of their maternal parent, a different female tree, or a male tree determined overall fungal diversity and drove the abundance of some fungal species. For example, growing in parent soil slightly increased overall fungal diversity. Together, these results show that fungal communities in tropical tree roots are shaped by a combination of resistance genes, soil environment, and genetic relatedness to nearby trees, and could play an important role in determining patterns of seedling fate and diversity in tropical forests.

Broader impacts: This project provided training and research experience in molecular genetics and bioinformatics to two Ph.D. students and three undergraduate students. In addition, this study yielded genetic information on a plethora of previously undescribed fungi in tropical soils. Knowledge of these fungi could benefit society by advancing the fields of agriculture and horticulture, particularly if any of the new fungi are pathogens or mutualists of economically important plants.
